Sphere <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>A</mtext></mstyle></math> is released at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math>, rises toward the surface, and at time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, Sphere <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>A</mtext></mstyle></math> is just below the surface of the water. The density of Sphere <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mtext>A</mtext> </mstyle> </math> is less than the density of water <math alttext="rho sub w" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. Resistive forces from the water are negligible.
content.question: (a) On the dot in Figure 2, which represents the sphere, draw and label the forces (not components) that are exerted on the sphere just after it is released from rest. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on and pointing away from the dot. Draw the relative lengths of all vectors to reflect the relative magnitudes of all the forces.

frqParts.text: (a) On the dot in Figure 2, which represents the sphere, draw and label the forces (not components) that are exerted on the sphere just after it is released from rest. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on and pointing away from the dot. Draw the relative lengths of all vectors to reflect the relative magnitudes of all the forces.

(b) Starting with Newton’s second law, derive an expression for the height of the sphere above the bottom of the pool as a function of time after time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math>, but before the sphere reaches the top of the water. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>m</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>r</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="rho sub w" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mstyle></math>,\(t\), and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference information.

(c) The pressure exerted by the water on the sphere at the bottom of the pool is <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. On the following grid, sketch the pressure exerted on the sphere by the water as a function of time from <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math>, to before the sphere reaches the surface of the water.

Sphere <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> takes time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> to travel from the bottom of the pool of water to just below the surface of the water. Sphere <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, which has the same radius as sphere <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> but mass <math alttext="2m" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> is released from rest at the bottom of the same pool of water.

(d) Justify why the time Sphere <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> takes to travel from the bottom of the pool to just below the surface of the water is greater than <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. Reference the free-body diagram you sketched in part (a) in your justification.
